titleInfo.title: Determinants of Presence in Virtual Reality Environments
titleInfo.subTitle: Examining the Role of Attention through a Novel Application of Feature Integration Theory

mods:mods.abstract: Immersive virtual reality (IVR) has shown promise in being an effective and cost-efficient method to deploy a variety of programs for promoting health, wellbeing, and physical and everyday functioning. The psychological construct of presence, often described as the "sense of being there," is considered a core aspect of the technology, and consequently a major facilitator of successful IVR experiences and interventions. While prior research has explored how individual difference factors and technology characteristics impact presence, relatively little is known about how the cognitive demands of the virtual experience itself could impact an individual's sense of being there. To that end, the current study investigated how the attentional demands of IVR experiences might influence presence. Within a virtual nature environment, participants were asked to "catch" different animals. Inspired by feature integration theory (FIT), different IVR scenarios involved search targets that varied in the degree to which attention was necessary to locate them (low-attention – similar to feature search; high-attention – similar to conjunction search). Initially, a small pilot study (N = 6, 4 female, mean age = 19) demonstrated that search targets and distractors chosen, when placed in a typical search paradigm, produced search efficiencies that varied significantly (set size by scenario interaction, F(1,32) = 8.42, p < 0.01, η²p = 0.21; low-attention slope: 33 ms/item, high-attention slope: 173 ms/item). Next, fifty participants (35 female, 1 non-binary, mean age = 19) engaged in an IVR foraging task in which they navigated the environment to collect these animals. Despite pilot and concurrent evidence that the two scenarios varied substantially and significantly in attentional demand, no effect of presence was observed (F(1, 49) = 0.69, p = 0.41, η²p = 0.01). Results suggest that different levels of visual attention to the virtual environment does not modulate presence.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Attention, Presence, Virtual Reality, Visual Search
Walter Boot, Professor Directing Thesis; Neil Charness, Committee Member; Sara Hart, Committee Member.
